metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with the airborne WiDAS mission in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas on Jul. 11, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with the airborne WiDAS mission was obtained in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas on Jul. 11, 2008. WiDAS, composed of four CCD cameras, one mid-infrared thermal imager (AGEMA 550), and one infrared thermal imager (S60), can acquire CCD, MIR and TIR band data. The simultaneous ground data included:
     (1) Atmospheric parameters in Huazhaizi desert No. 2 plot from CE318 (produced by CIMEL in France). The total optical depth, aerosol optical depth, Rayleigh scattering coefficient, column water vapor in 936 nm, particle size spectrum and phase function were then retrieved from these observations. The optical depth in 1020nm, 936nm, 870nm, 670nm and 440nm were all acquired by CE318. Those data include the raw data in k7 format and can be opened by ASTPWin. ReadMe.txt is attached for details. Processed data (after retrieval of the raw data) in Excel format are on optical depth, Rayleigh scattering, aerosol optical depth, the horizontal visibility, the near surface air temperature, the solar azimuth, zenith, solar distance correlation factors, and air column mass number. 
     (2) Radiative temperature of maize, wheat and the bare land (in Yingke oasis maize field), vegetation and the bare land (Huazhaizi desert No. 2 plot) by the thermal cameras at a height of 1.2m above the ground. Optical photos of the scene were also taken. Raw data (read by ThermaCAM Researcher 2001) was archived in IMG format and radiative files are stored in Excel format. .
     (3) Photosynthesis by LI6400 in Yingke oasis maize field, carried out according to WATER specifications. Raw data were archived in the user-defined format  (by notepat.exe) and processed data were in Excel format.
     (4) Ground object reflectance spectra in Yingke oasis maize field, Huazhaizi maize field, Huazhaizi desert No. 1 and 2 plots, by ASD FieldSpec (350～2500 nm) from Institute of Remote Sensing Applications (IRSA), CAS. Raw data were binary files direct from ASD (by ViewSpecPro), which were recorded daily in detail, and pre-processed data on reflectance were in .txt format.
     (5) The radiative temperature in Huazhaizi desert No. 2 plot by the handheld infrared thermometer (BNU and IRSA). Raw data, blackbody calibrated data and processed data (in Excel format) were all archived.
     (6) FPAR (Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation) by SUNSACN and the digital camera in Yingke oasis maize field. FPAR= (canopyPAR－surface transmissionPAR－canopy reflection PAR+surface reflectionPAR) /canopy PAR; APAR=FPAR* canopy PAR. Data were archived in Excel format.
     (7) The radiative temperature of the maize canopy by the automatic thermometer (FOV: 10°; emissivity: 0.95) mearsued at nadir with an time intervals of 1s in Huazhaizi desert maize field. Raw data, blackbody calibrated data and processed data were all archived as Excel files.
     (8) Maize albedo from two shortwave radiometer in Yingke oasis maize field. R =10H (R for FOV radius; H for the probe height). Data were archived in Excel format.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather atmospheric parameters in desert environments?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to gather atmospheric parameters in desert environments is the use of the CE318 sun photometer, which measures direct solar radiation to retrieve optical thickness, Rayleigh scattering, aerosol optical thickness, and atmospheric water vapor content.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes measured by a wide-angle infrared dual-mode line/area array scanner in a dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: visible/near-infrared bands at five angles, mid-infrared bands at seven angles, thermal infrared bands at seven angles, canopy radiation temperature, vegetation photosynthesis rate, albedo, FPAR, atmospheric parameters

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of various remote sensing instruments like CCD cameras, thermal imagers, and solar spectrometers improve the accuracy and depth of environmental data collection in desert and oasis regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing instruments such as CCD cameras, thermal imagers, and solar spectrometers can enhance data collection by providing a comprehensive dataset across different spectral bands and observational angles. This multi-instrument approach allows for capturing detailed information on canopy radiation temperature, vegetation photosynthesis rate, and atmospheric parameters. Each instrument contributes unique data points; for example, CCD cameras capture visible and near-infrared angles, while infrared thermal imagers provide surface temperature data. The combination allows for cross-verification of data, improved calibration, and a more holistic understanding of environmental conditions in diverse landscapes like deserts and oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of accurately capturing surface temperature data using thermal imaging in diverse terrains such as oases and deserts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity of accurately capturing surface temperature data using thermal imaging in diverse terrains such as oases and deserts can be attributed to various factors. These include the heterogeneity of land cover types like maize fields, wheat fields, and bare soil, which require precise calibration and correction for emissivity. Additionally, the varying angles and heights of measurement, as well as the need for simultaneous optical imaging for context, add to the challenges. The necessity to calibrate instruments like thermal imagers with blackbody data and the influence of atmospheric parameters on thermal readings also contribute to the complexity.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in synchronizing ground-based and airborne data collection for infrared imaging in desert and oasis environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The synchronization involves using the Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner (WiDAS), which includes CCD cameras and thermal imagers to collect visible, near-infrared, mid-infrared, and thermal infrared data simultaneously. Ground-based measurements include canopy radiation temperature, photosynthesis rate, albedo, FPAR, and atmospheric parameters. Instruments like CE318 sun photometer, thermal imagers, and spectrometers are utilized to gather complementary atmospheric and surface data, which are then processed and calibrated for analysis.
